 MLD

Detailed Description

Keeps track of a connection.

This class opens a CODgram to a remote host, and keeps track of connection state information (ie SessionKey, header sequence info, etc...). This should be contained in a Packet message so that the server knows who to respond to, and who it is dispatching commands for.

Peer::Peer ( const ACE_INET_Addr & remote,
const ACE_INET_Addr & local,
Peer_Manager * peer_manager,
Thread_Timer_Queue * _timer_queue )
 

Constructor using open method.

Passes all args to the open method. Using the do nothing constructor and then calling open is the preffered way to initialize a Peer object because then you can catch errors more easily.

Uninitialized a Peer object.

This is the counterpart to the open method. It disconnects the CODgram and cleans up its members.

Member Data Documentation

Peer::MLD [protected]
 

ARQ_Cache_T Peer::arq_cache_ [protected]
 

This is used to keep track of which ARQ's we have received.

This is implemented as a Red-Black Binary Tree. When an ARQ is received from the peer, it is added to this cache. If it already exists in the three, then the packet is ignored. Otherwise, the tree is checked to see if the ARQ we just received is the next expected ARQ. If it the ARQ we expect, then the last_peer_ack is set to this new value, and the arq_timer_id is started if it is not already active.

long Peer::arq_timer_id_ [protected]
 

This is the timer we use to send responses back to the peer.

This timer is cancelled if a packet is sent out to the peer with a response bit set before this timeout is triggered. This is used in case we have a significant delay before another packet is sent, and it helps increase throughput.

long Peer::buffer_sent_ [protected]
 

Keeps track of how much data we have sent out which hasn't been responded to.

ACE_SOCK_CODgram Peer::dgram_ [protected]
 

int Peer::is_open_ [protected]
 

ACE_UINT16 Peer::last_peer_ack_ [protected]
 

This is the last valid ARQ we have received from the peer.

Although we may have received ARQ's higher than this, this is the last consecutive ARQ we have received. This will be the ARSP sent to the peer on the next arq_timer_id timeout, or on the next regular packet with the ARSP bit set, whichever is first.

ACE_INET_Addr* Peer::remote_ [protected]
 

Send_Queue_T Peer::send_queue_ [protected]
 

This is the queue we keep outgoing packets in.

This queue serves two purposes. First, it acts as a FIFO buffer for out outgoing message so that they are not all sent in large bursts. Secondly, it is used to keep track of which packets haven't been acknowledged, so that they can still timeout and resend themselves.
